implementation uses simple commitment-based verification      Future upgrade path to Groth16 verifier  MVP Commitment Scheme: - Users register a commitment: keccak256(abi.encodePacked(secret, nullifier)) - To verify, users provide (secret, nullifier) and we recompute the hash - This proves they know the secret without revealing it on-chain  Future Groth16 Upgrade: - Replace hash verification with zkSNARK proof verification - Use Groth16 verifier contract for cryptographic proof validation - Integrate with circom circuits for eligibility and range returns._0: bool True if user has active commitment

owner().details: Returns the address of the current owner.

registerCommitment(bytes32).details: Users must register before they can be verified      Commitment = keccak256(abi.encodePacked(secret, nullifier))

params.commitment: The hash commitment (hash of secret + nullifier)

renounceOwnership().details: Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call `onlyOwner` functions. Can only be called by the current owner. NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner, thereby disabling any functionality that is only available to the owner.

setRangeCommitment(uint256,address,bytes.details: This allows holders to commit to their balance for future range proofs

params.commitment: The commitment hash for range proof

transferOwnership(address).details: Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`). Can only be called by the current owner.

updateHolderVerification(uint256,address.details: Allows admin to manually verify token holders

verifyEligibility(address,bytes32,bytes).details: MVP: Verifies that keccak256(proof) matches stored commitment      Future: Will use Groth16 verifier for full zkSNARK verification

params.proof: ZK proof data containing (secret, nullifier) as abi.encodePacked
params.user: Address of the user to verify

verifyRangeProof(uint256,address,uint256.details: MVP: Simple eligibility check + range validation      Future: Full Groth16 range proof circuit verification            The range proof allows a holder to prove their balance is within      [minRange, maxRange] without revealing the exact amount.            For Groth16 upgrade, proof will contain:      - Private inputs: actualAmount, secret      - Public inputs: minRange, maxRange, commitment      - Proof that minRange <= actualAmount <= maxRange

returns._0: bool True if the holder's balance is within [minRange, maxRange]

getCommitment(address).notice: Get commitment details for a user

hasActiveCommitment(address).notice: Check if a user has an active commitment

registerCommitment(bytes32).notice: Register a commitment for a user

setRangeCommitment(uint256,address,bytes.notice: Set range commitment for a token holder

updateHolderVerification(uint256,address.notice: Update verification status for a token holder

verifyEligibility(address,bytes32,bytes).notice: Verify user eligibility using ZK proof

verifyRangeProof(uint256,address,uint256.notice: Verify range proof for token holdings
